stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the whole session defining the new Western-themed Course 12—tentatively "Wild West Valley." He revises the visual style, colour palette, fog settings and overall layout, sketches the level flow in MS-Paint, and locks in core gameplay concepts such as three mini-boss “outlaw” stars and a rideable train that links the town and the mine. Much of the discussion revolves around making wooden buildings pop within N64 limits while maintaining a cartoon vibe. A new Western music track from Badub arrives mid-stream and becomes a creative anchor.

development_findings.summary: Course 12 will contain three interconnected sub-areas: a main town, a valley playground, and a train headquarters/gold mine. A train links area 1 and 3, while area 2 can be walked as an alternative route.
development_findings.quote: We’re going to have a town area, then after the town there will be a valley area, and after the valley area there will be the train headquarters. You can go from the first town to the train headquarters, and from the train headquarters back around to the first town.

development_findings.summary: Each of the three outlaw mini-bosses awards a star and is jailed after defeat: a saloon Snuffit shoot-out, a Monty Mole bank robber traced via digging trail, and five Goombas in a trench coat who robbed a train.
development_findings.quote: There will be three bosses here, they're all small bosses, and every single one of them will be a star. And you will put them in jail after you catch them.

development_findings.summary: The level opens with the jail directly in Mario’s view so players immediately receive objectives from the sheriff NPC.
development_findings.quote: Mario has to be looking straight at the jail at the start.

development_findings.summary: A constant-looping train will run on two heights: ground-level tracks in town and elevated “sky” tracks that pass over the player for visual flair and fast travel.
development_findings.quote: You will see the train drive over Mario… another train is coming from here… everything past here will be off screen.

development_findings.summary: Kaze battles with building aesthetics—testing saturation, complementary colours, blue vs orange fog, wood textures, and references (Wario’s Gold Mine, Hidden Village TP, Mario Party Western Land, Odyssey’s Sand Kingdom). He settles on bright cartoon colours with blue fog.
development_findings.quote: Finding the art style always takes a while… I think we can go with the style. I think Blue fog is good to go.

development_findings.summary: Global fog on N64 forces 2-cycle materials, potentially harming performance; Kaze weighs visuals against hardware limits.
development_findings.quote: Unfortunately, this means everything is going to be a 2-cycle material, which is really, really bad… It might just look so good that we have to take the loss.

development_findings.summary: Uses Fast64 (Blender plug-in) to export geometry into SM64 decomp; Nintendo DMCA’d previous tutorials.
development_findings.quote: There's a plugin called Fast64. You can just export levels from it into Decomp. Nintendo took all my tutorials down.

development_findings.summary: NPC/asset list includes Yoshi cowboys (as horses), Cowboy Toads, tumbleweeds, giant cacti, Pokies, Bandits, Chain Chomps, wanted posters, rocking chairs and milk-only saloon dialogue sourced from the Cowboy Cats Instagram account.
Level geometry will form a donut/U-shape mountain for aggressive culling; Kaze draws this in MS-Paint to plan height tiers, tunnels and platform routes.
development_findings.quote: What if this whole city was kind of around a mountain? That would work well for the N64 because of how much culling it allows.

development_findings.summary: Development pace slowed after Course 9 because Kaze now holds a full-time job.
development_findings.quote: Development has slowed down ever since the end of course 9, because I have a full-time job now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s guiding principle is ‘rule of cool’—fun and visual appeal override realism.
context_findings.quote: This is not about logic, this is about cool. Rule of cool is the rule here.

context_findings.summary: Excitement spike when Badub delivers the new Western track; it immediately shapes visual decisions.
context_findings.quote: Oh, this is so perfect. I love this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze takes a firm stance against alcohol and places milk jokes in the saloon.
context_findings.quote: I think drinking is just not a good thing to do. Don't drink, it's that simple.

context_findings.summary: He expresses indifference toward current Twitch drama and focuses on productivity.
context_findings.quote: I actually care so little about the whole Twitch nudity thing… Just ignore it. How is it affecting me?

context_findings.summary: Mentions bodybuilding diet ratios when asked by chat, revealing personal fitness interest.
context_findings.quote: Nutrition is actually pretty simple for bodybuilding… usually 30–40% protein, 30–40% carbs, 30–40% fat.

biobak.summary: Actively critiques building colour choices, suggesting higher saturation and Odyssey-style palettes.
biobak.quote: Giving it the most charitable possible interpretation, I think what you're saying is to make them more saturated. Is that correct?

badub.summary: Delivers a bespoke three-and-a-half-minute Western track during the stream, instantly approved by Kaze and influencing fog decisions.
badub.quote: He just sent me that… I'm assuming he made this for this level.

zeina.summary: Not directly active during the stream; Kaze notes her arrival home but no project input captured.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Cowboy Art Style
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles to make Western buildings pop without breaking N64 limits. He cycles through references, colour sliders and fog tests while Biobak critiques and Badub’s music inspires final choices.
key_stories.challenge: Initial buildings felt flat, oversaturated or ‘monocolour’ against canyon textures.
key_stories.process: Iterated textures, tested blue vs orange fog, swapped wooden planks, consulted references (Wario’s Gold Mine, Sand Kingdom) and audience feedback.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on bright cartoon palette, blue fog and simplified wood textures as the working style to proceed with block-out.
key_stories.key_quote: Finding the art style always takes a while... I think Blue fog is good to go.

key_stories.title: Designing the Bank-Robbing Monty Mole
key_stories.summary: Kaze crafts an interactive mini-boss where a Monty Mole tunnels into the bank and leaves a trail the player must follow.
key_stories.challenge: Wanted a unique star that fit the outlaw theme and used level geography.
key_stories.process: Sketched trail path in MS-Paint, placed bank near saloon, planned dig trail leading to a hidden boss arena.
key_stories.outcome: Concept locked; will implement continuous, height-consistent mole trail and boss fight awarding a star.
key_stories.key_quote: There will be a Monty Mole that has robbed the bank… all you see is a trail and this trail will lead to the culprit.

key_stories.title: Music Breakthrough on Stream
key_stories.summary: Mid-stream, composer Badub sends a surprise Western track that immediately defines the level’s atmosphere.
key_stories.challenge: Needed audio identity to match new level.
key_stories.process: Badub composes and messages Kaze; Kaze previews it live, reacts enthusiastically and tests fog/sky colours against it.
key_stories.outcome: Track adopted as Course 12 theme; visuals adjusted (decision to add fog) to complement the music.
key_stories.key_quote: This is so perfect. I love this.

open_questions.context: Kaze tentatively approves a colourful style but is still unsure about roofs, window triangles and saturation balance.
questions: What definitive colour rules or reference sheet will you and Biobak use going forward?
How will textures be authored to stay within 64×64 limits without losing clarity?
What is the workflow for testing buildings on real N64 hardware?

open_questions.context: Global fog forces 2-cycle materials, risking frame-rate drops.
questions: What concrete performance budget do you have for Course 12?
Are alternative fog implementations or hardware tricks possible to avoid 2-cycle cost?
Will you ship with a toggle or LOD system for older flashcarts?

open_questions.context: Plan involves continuous moving train, sky tracks, fast travel and culling tricks.
questions: How will the train’s logic, collision and camera work on N64?
What failures or derailment states need to be prevented?
How are area transitions handled when riding the train?

open_questions.context: Badub delivered a key track spontaneously.
questions: What is the creative brief you give Badub for composing?
How do you convert modern audio to N64 format while retaining quality?
Will dynamic music (e.g., saloon interior) be used?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes a sign-based clue chain but no details.
questions: What puzzles or landmarks will anchor each clue?
How do you ensure players don’t get stuck in a nonlinear playground?
Could Yoshi Coins tie into the hunt?

open_questions.context: Yoshis may function as horses, implying new animations.
questions: What technical steps are required for rideable Yoshi cowboys?
Is Zeina handling these animations and how will they be rigged?
Will this mechanic appear elsewhere in the hack?

open_questions.topic: Team Coordination under Kaze’s Full-Time Job
questions: How is the team scheduling tasks and milestones now?
What tools are used for version control and communication?
Does Kaze delegate more to Biobak, Badub or Zeina to compensate?

open_questions.context: Nintendo removed Kaze’s tutorials; hack legality is always in question.
questions: What precautions are you taking for eventual public release?
Will you distribute via patch files only?
Are you prepared for potential takedown requests?
